column4: Does anyone know if the i386 Ubuntu kernels have SMP (multi processor core) support?
Is it possible to reboot from the commandline withouth superuser previliegs?
!ru | DODrive
no, that would be a major problem
what happens when I shutdown trough the System menu then? Some signal is sent to init or something? I mean, I don'tneed to be su to do that
GDM runs as root, and i think GDM is configured to accept commands like that from users who have logged in though gdm
ah ok
yes, grub runs in stages :-) it is hard-coded in the mbr where to look for the stage 1.5 files, including menu.lst
yeah, but doesn't the root (hd0,1) tell it where to look for menu.lst?
no -- how would it know to read hd0,1 if it can't read the menu.lst?
from what I understand, GRUB is hd aware?
doesn't one have to tell it where to find menu.lst?
yes, you do that when you install grub onto the mbr
ok, so to conquer GRUB from SUSE, I need to overwrite the MBR with my own MBR, I can't set the root partion where GRUB should look for menu.lst afterwards?
when you install grub you specify the partition that the menu.lst is on, so you need to reinstall grub to point to the ubuntu partition (you can do this in ubuntu or suse, it doesn't matter)
actually, you might need to be in ubuntu to do it
if you are in ubuntu (or can chroot into it) you can use grub-install
so the root command (from the GRUB shell) is only local to a particular shell session? I thought that command wrote which partion to look in to the MBR...
nah, how could this be Ubuntu specific?
if there is a way to specify where to look for the 1.5 files you could do that
i think the default behavior is to just look in /boot/grub/
yes, the problem is how to tell GRUB where root is?
usually if I want to change it and I am not in the correct place, I chroot to the install I want to install it from and run grub-install from the chroot
